awd_abstract_narration:
As a simple technology for handling liquid droplets, electrically making a liquid wetting on a non-wettable surface, i.e., electrowetting, especially electrowetting-on-dielectric (EWOD) technology, has shown significant progress since the turn of the century. While major commercial products have started to emerge, the well-known reliability problem of EWOD devices is hampering the continued growth. A UCLA team from the engineering and medical school proposes to explore a phenomenon opposite to electrowetting, thus named electrodewetting, after finding it has a droplet manipulation capability similar to EWOD without the reliability problem. Noting the high reliability and easy manufacturing of electrodewetting-based devices, the team proposes to study the origin of electrodewetting, characterize the mechanism, and build the fundamental knowledge that will help design application devices. The proposed electrodewetting study is expected to significantly increase the user base of digital (droplet) microfluidics, which is powered by EWOD technology currently. Attractive to users of all levels and different goals regardless of their expertise and interests, electrodewetting devices are expected to serve both academic and industrial researchers as well as some hobbyists because of their simplicity and reliability. The proposed work requires an interdisciplinary approach in research and training on issues ranging from basic electrical engineering, surface science, and microfabrication, all the way to optical and biochemical applications. Graduate students will gain first-hand experience from this interdisciplinary research and be well prepared to be future leaders. Undergraduate and high school students will carry out tasks in a vertical team of researchers. The results will enrich the engineering curricula, including the MEMS/Nano PhD program at UCLA. 
      
While providing all the basic digital microfluidic functions of EWOD, electrodewetting avoids the key problems of EWOD. First, electrodewetting uses a hydrophilic substrate with neither the dielectric layer nor the hydrophobic topcoat. These coated layers needed for EWOD are the main culprits to its reliability problem and high manufacturing cost. Hydrophilic surfaces, such as glass, are common to many diverse applications spanning biomedical, optical, chemical, and other fields. Importantly, this simplicity would also make the design and manufacturing of electrodewetting devices easy and cheap. Second, electrodewetting typically uses only ~3 V for actuation. This low voltage allows the use off-the-shelf integrated circuits so the developers can quickly build a compact system, which is especially useful for mobile applications. Third, droplets can be split into smaller ones in an open configuration with no cover plate, allowing more flexibility in device design. In the proposed study, based on hypotheses carefully constructed from preliminary experiments and observations, the UCLA team will elucidate how the electrodewetting mechanism works, understand how it responds to device parameters, build the fundamental engineering knowledge for device design, and explore applications by developing an electronic display device. The underlying goal is to develop knowledge foundation that will assist other researchers and developers who would like to adopt this elegantly simple liquid handling technology for their own applications.
org_div_long_name: Division of Electrical, Communications and Cyber Systems

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: REU SUPP-Res Exp for Ugrd Supp

por.por_cntn:
Intellectual merit:

As an elegant technology to handle liquid droplets on chip, electrowetting – especially electrowetting-on-dielectric (EWOD) technology – has shown explosive progress since the turn of the century, and major commercial products have started to emerge in recent years. However, the well-known reliability issues, which stem from the dielectric and hydrophobic coatings needed for EWOD, significantly limits the successful applications. A UCLA team has discovered a phenomenon opposite to electrowetting, thus named electrodewetting, and found that it has a droplet handling capability like EWOD without requiring the dielectric or hydrophobic coating. To explore this new mechanism, the goals of the project were to (1) understand the underlying principles, (2) characterize how key parameters affect the performance, and (3) explore application opportunities of electrodewetting.

While a droplet can only spread on a substrate by applying a voltage between them – thus electrowetting, the UCLA team enabled the opposite (beading up) by adding a dilute amount of surfactant in the droplet. As illustrated in the accompanied figure, when a proper electric current is applied, an electric field attracts the charged surfactant molecules onto the substrate so that the surfactant repels the droplet (top figure). When the current is reversed, the surfactant is removed from the substrate so that the droplet is naturally spread on the substrate (bottom figure). In addition to the theoretical and experimental verification of the electrodewetting mechanism as proposed, a mathematical model has also been developed by a collaborating group.

To build fundamental knowledge of electrodewetting for device design and manufacturing, the team has characterized the effects of surfactant type, concentration, and actuation voltage on the contact angle change and dewetting time. An effective surfactant concentration range and required voltage have been identified. A digital microfluidics device was demonstrated that can perform four basic droplet operations (droplet dispensing, transportation, cutting, and merging) with only about 5 V, and a fabrication process was developed to manufacture the devices. During the study, a unique property of electrodewetting, such as bistability, was discovered at certain conditions, which indicates that the droplet can maintain its state of spreading or beading even after the electric actuation is removed.

Broader Impacts:

As a disruptive platform technology, electrodewetting has the potential to enable numerous applications with its simplicity in device fabrication, reliability in device operation, and bistability for energy saving. In the project, the UCLA team has not only established the fundamental knowledge of electrodewetting but also demonstrated its utility for digital microfluidics, which will enable others to discover and develop more applications. As a multi-physics phenomenon demonstrated and characterized by the UCLA team, electrodewetting will motivate and advance scientific research in various fields, including surfactant chemistry and electrochemistry.

Through the project, one postdoc, three graduate students, ten undergraduate students, and three high school students have gained valuable research experience. The research results have been integrated into undergraduate and graduate courses to enrich the curricula at UCLA. The project outcome has been widely disseminated through scientific publications, conference presentations, invited seminars, and lab websites, drawing interests and inspiring more ideas.


Last Modified: 07/04/2022
Modified by: Chang-Jin Kim

Image
  • Schematic illustration of how the surfactant-mediated electrodewetting works
    Jia Li and CJ Kim
    Chang-Jin Kim
    The mechanism
